content.question: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. The manufacturer of a certain type of new cell phone battery claims that the average life span of the batteries is <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges; that is, the battery can be charged at least <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> times before failing. To investigate the claim, a consumer group will select a random sample of cell phones with the new battery and use the phones through <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges of the battery. The proportion of batteries that fail to last through <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges will be recorded. The results will be used to construct a <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval to estimate the proportion of all such batteries that fail to last through <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges.(a) Explain in context what it means to be <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confident.

frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. The manufacturer of a certain type of new cell phone battery claims that the average life span of the batteries is <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges; that is, the battery can be charged at least <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> times before failing. To investigate the claim, a consumer group will select a random sample of cell phones with the new battery and use the phones through <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges of the battery. The proportion of batteries that fail to last through <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges will be recorded. The results will be used to construct a <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval to estimate the proportion of all such batteries that fail to last through <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges.(a) Explain in context what it means to be <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confident.

(b) Suppose the consumer group conducts its investigation with a random sample of <math alttext="5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> cell phones with the new battery, and <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> battery out of the <math alttext="5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> fails to last through <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges. Verify all conditions for inference for a <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for a population proportion. Indicate whether any condition has not been met. Do not construct the interval. In some studies, large sample sizes are not feasible because of the time and expense involved. However, small sample sizes can create issues with inference procedures. A simulation can be used to investigate what might happen with intervals constructed from small sample sizes. Consider a population in which <math alttext="30"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent of the population displays a certain characteristic. For each trial of the simulation, <math alttext="5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> observations are selected from the population and the sample proportion <math alttext="p hat"><mrow><mover><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></math> is calculated, where <math alttext="p hat"><mrow><mover><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></math> represents the proportion in the sample that display the characteristic. The following table shows the frequency distribution of <math alttext="p hat"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math> in the <math alttext="1,000"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> trials. Also shown are the upper and lower endpoints of a <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence created from the value of <math alttext="p hat"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>, using the formula <math alttext="p hat plus or minus 1.96, times the square root of, the fraction with numerator, p hat times open parenthesis, 1 minus p hat, close parenthesis, and denominator n"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mo>±</mo><mrow><mn>1.96</mn><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. For example, the sample proportion of <math alttext="0.4"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> occurred <math alttext="309"><mstyle><mrow><mn>309</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> times in the <math alttext="1,000"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> trials and produced a confidence interval of <math alttext="negative 0.029, comma 0.829"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.029</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0.829</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="p hat"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math> Frequency Lower Endpoint Upper Endpoint <math alttext="0"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="168"><mstyle><mrow><mn>168</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.551"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.551</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.4"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="309"><mstyle><mrow><mn>309</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="negative 0.029"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.029</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.829"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.829</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.6"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="133"><mstyle><mrow><mn>133</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.171"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.171</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.029"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.029</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.8"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.151"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.151</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.0"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(c) Based on the simulation, what proportion of the <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence intervals capture the population proportion of <math alttext="0.3"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain how you determined your answer.

(d) For small sample sizes, an alternate method of constructing a confidence interval is available. To implement this method, first, include an additional <math alttext="4"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> observations in the sample, <math alttext="2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of which are successes and <math alttext="2"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of which are failures. Second, calculate a new sample proportion <math alttext="p hat sub new"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mtext>new</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></math> for the new sample. Finally, construct a confidence interval using <math alttext="p hat sub new"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mtext>new</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, with the formula <math alttext="p hat sub new, plus or minus 1.96, times the square root of, the fraction with numerator, p hat sub new, times open parenthesis, 1 minus p hat sub new, close parenthesis, and denominator n plus 4, end fraction, end root"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">w</mi></mrow></msub><mo>±</mo><mn>1.96</mn><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>new</mtext></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>new</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>. (i) For the cell phone batteries, consider a sample of <math alttext="5"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> in which <math alttext="1"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> battery fails to last through <math alttext="500"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> charges. Using the alternate method described, what is the value of <math alttext="p hat sub new"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mtext>new</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></math>? Show your work. The following table shows the results of the original simulation with revised <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence intervals constructed with the alternate method. Original <math alttext="p hat"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math> Frequency Revised Lower Endpoint Revised Upper Endpoint <math alternate method better than the traditional method described in part (b) to construct a <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval with a small sample size? Explain your reasoning.

topic.text: 1.7: Summary Statistics for a Quantitative Variable

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Calculate summary statistics, relative positions of points within a distribution, correlation, and predicted response.
